meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Balskus (Harvard University)

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Balskus (Harvard University)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, so maybe we can start by just kind of sharing anything that stood out as you're kind of thinking about this topic.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake (Yale)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm biased as an immunologist, so my answer is to a lot of them is we'll probably look the immune system um serving as a go between between the gut in this case um and the brain or or thereabouts.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake (Yale)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, but I'm curious to see what others have to to add to that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jaeyun Jae Sung (Mayo Clinic)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I don't follow this um area of of research that well, but I know there's a lot of people working on um kind of hunger appetite regulation and the gut microbiome um you know, the the gut has a, you know, it produces its own hormones for hunger regulation. It produces ghrelin, it produces leptin. Um so and and and at least in mice and I think also in humans as well, again, I don't follow this literature, but there's been a lot of regulation um there's been a lot of evidence shown that the gut microbiome does instigate the production of these hunger hormones from the gut. Um I don't know if that's has to do with the brain though. I apologize.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake (Yale)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Probably does. Wouldn't it be interpreted in the brain?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jaeyun Jae Sung (Mayo Clinic)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, right, right.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Melanie Gareau (UC Davis)
meeting_annotations.transcript: And the vagus is important for satiety. There's vagal afference and they communicate with the nodes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: It would be important to consider in what way we're thinking about this information transfer. For example, acute information such as hunger and satiety or chronic information meaning uh you know, long long lived uh ongoing, you know, steady state dynamics.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Because both have have to be a source of information, right? But they must somehow be different. So I don't know exactly how, but I think maybe it depends which how you want to think of the information you know, something you need right away or something that you just need to interpret as as a baseline.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: The other thing I think about a lot in my lab is region specific dynamics uh host microbe dynamics. I mean, this is going to be different not only small intestine versus colon, but even different in duodenum, jejunum versus ileum.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh we know from our own experiments that there are region specific.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: So um I mean even in a simple sense, the small intestine has doesn't have this strong fortified mucus barrier in the same way the colon does.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: You know, the colon basically has like a hardcore fence of of mucus preventing microbes from touching the epithelium.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Whereas the small intestine has a what they call a porous mucus layer and even discontinuous, so there are gaps in it if you will.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I I think it also depends where you're thinking this information is coming from and also the fact that those things can be changing, you know, the food is constantly moving.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Mucus has to be continuously produced, there are also mucin mucin degrading microbes. I don't know there's so many of them, but there are some.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um and then if we're thinking about an immune uh response in all of this, you still have to also think about acute or chronic because there will be an acute response when a new microbe is introduced or an infectious something, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: There'll be an acute response, but then there's also just the standard cell types that live there and do their jobs every day.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: So there's I feel like it's important to to kind of piece it out first as to where we want to tackle those questions because it may be different in all those different contexts as well as regions.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake (Yale)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Dan, I think your point about the regional specificity is so interesting and important. I'm curious how as a mucosal biologist is are you able to study that in humans at all or is it limited to model systems and and how would we determine what the applicability was between say the mouse and the human in that context.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's a really good question.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: You know, it's not so easy to get access.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Along the length of the small bowel from human you know, people. Um I one one outlet can be from adult donor tissue, you know, that that's uh healthy for transplant, but it's not actually transplanted, but these are very expensive source.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um in the study I'm involved in, it's something like almost $3,000 per you know, tissue and you of course have to have a surgeon who who is doing this. So I I don't think that the way we do the experiments in the mouse are as easily you know, to get the same kind of information from human.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sadly no.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sadly no.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh, but you're better off. Everybody's better off with colon.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gianna Hammer (Duke (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Colon biopsies are much easier to come by. That's for sure. Yes.
